ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned basic Korean grammar and vocabulary.
I learned the Korean alphabet, Korean vocabulary, grammar patterns (past, present, future tense, and more), and how to read, write, listen, and speak Korean.

I learned a surprising amount about the Korean language throughout the semester! I feel like I learned the basics very quickly and thoroughly through this class, and building on the basics, enough grammar to be able to carry out a conversation in Korean.
This course develops knowledge of the Korean alphabet, basic conversational skills in Korean, and an ability to read anything and everything (without necessarily understanding).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The classroom environment was always incredibly fun. At times, it felt that the class moved too quickly, but that was to be expected with any language course. I am overall incredibly excited by the amount of Korean I was able to learn in a semester

Lee-seonsaengnim is the strength of this course.  She is so patient and moves at the speed of class.  She quickly gives feedback (returns homeworks and quizzes) so the pace of learning is not hindered.   She cares greatly for students learning Korean and for students' well-being in general. I think a two day notice before quizzes would be helpful for future iterations of the class just so people have more time to study and internalize the vocabulary.  Besides that, I'm glad there were no tests and just speaking projects because I think it's more practical for language usage.   I genuinely think Lee-seonsaengnim is geniunely one of the best teachers I've had at Yale and this was one my favorite classes of the semester!

Strengths: THE PROFESSOR. SHE IS SUCH AN ANGEL. Always made sure to answer any questions and help out if anyone is struggling. The content was also never too unmanageable. 
Weaknesses: Nothing really.
The course was easy to follow and at a pace that everyone could follow. The availability of a teaching fellow was also very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I think that Korean is a great language to start at L1

Yes totally!  Especially with Lee-seonsaengnim!  Korean has a steep learning curve coming from English but the way she teaches makes it easier to learn.  I feel confident in my basic "survival" Korean skills and I am so excited to learn more of the language next semester!
I would say no just to gatekeep it, but yes, it is a great course and if you can, take it with Professor Lee-Smith.

Yes!! Highly recommend! The course is not only fun and engaging to learn, but also a great place to make new friends and form a fun community. The course is a good balance of challenging/educational and fun/lower-stress.
Absolutely. The instructor is so full of joy and contagious energy, making learning a new and sometimes difficult language fun!
